Situation1: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: You are scheduled to be a guest on a live radio show to discuss your cause, and the segment starts in five minutes.
Story: The register beeped as I scanned the last few items, my eyes darting between the screen and the clock above the counter. My shift was supposed to end ten minutes ago, but a rush of customers had kept me glued to the till. Now, I was handling a high-value transaction, counting bills and coins with trembling fingers, knowing that any mistake could mean a long, stressful audit. At the same time, my phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder that I was due on air in five minutes to talk about the campaign I’d poured my heart into. The radio host was counting on me to educate listeners, to inspire action. My manager expected flawless accuracy, no shortcuts. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility to my job and the commitment to my cause. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing down, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
